french: ESTANT assis de nuict secret estude,
Seul reposé sur la selle d'aerain :
Flambe exigue sortant de sollitude,
Fait prosperer qui n'est à croire vain.
english: Sitting at night in secret study,
Alone resting on the brass tripod:
A slight flame coming out of the solitude
Makes prosper that which is not vain to believe.
1.interpretation: This famous opening quatrain describes Nostradamus himself in the act of prophecy. He sits alone at night, using a brass tripod (reminiscent of the Delphic oracle), and through a small flame emerging from solitude, he achieves success in pronouncing prophecies that are not vain to believe. It sets the mystical tone for the entire work and reveals his method of scrying or meditative trance.

french: La verge en main mise au milieu de Branches,
De l'onde il moulle & le limbe & le pied :
Un peur & voix fremissent par les manches :
Splendeur diuine. Le diuin pres s'assied.
english: The rod in hand placed in the middle of Branches,
With the wave he wets both the hem and the foot:
A fear and voice tremble through the sleeves:
Divine splendor. The divine sits near.
2.interpretation: Nostradamus continues describing his ritual: holding a rod or wand amid laurel branches (evoking Branchus, son of Apollo, and the Delphic tripod), wetting the hem of his robe and his foot with water, trembling with fear and a quavering voice as divine splendor manifests and the divine presence draws near to sit beside him. This reinforces the sacred, priestly nature of his prophetic sessions.

french: Quand la lictiere du tourbillon versee,
Et feront faces de leurs manteaux couverts,
La republique par gens nouveaux vexee,
Lors blancs & rouges jugeront à l'envers.
english: When the litter is overturned by the whirlwind,
And faces will be covered by their cloaks,
The republic will be vexed by new people,
Then whites and reds will judge backwards.
3.interpretation: This quatrain is often linked to the French Revolution: the royal litter overturned in a whirlwind of upheaval, faces hidden under cloaks (suggesting disguise or mourning), a republic harassed by newcomers in power, and the colors white (royalist/Bourbon) and red (revolutionary) judging in perverse or inverted ways amid the chaos.

french: Par l'univers sera faict un Monarque,
Qu'en paix & vie ne sera longuement :
Lors se perdra la piscature barque,
Sera regie en plus grand detriment.
english: Throughout the universe will be made a Monarch,
Who in peace and life will not be for long:
Then will be lost the fishing bark,
It will be governed to greater detriment.
4.interpretation: This quatrain predicts the rise of a universal monarch—possibly a global empire or hegemonic leader—whose reign brings only brief peace. The 'fishing bark' (the Barque of St. Peter, symbol of the Catholic Church) is lost, implying the Church's authority collapses under his rule, leading to governance that causes even greater harm and spiritual ruin.

french: Chassez seront pour faire long combat,
Par le pays seront plus fort grevez :
Bourg & cité auront plus grand debat,
Carcat. Narbonne auront cueurs esprouvez.
english: They will be chased to wage long combat,
Throughout the country they will be more strongly oppressed:
Town and city will have greater debate,
Carcassonne, Narbonne will have their hearts tested.
5.interpretation: Pursued forces are driven into prolonged warfare across the land, causing intense suffering. Towns and cities erupt in fierce disputes, while the southern French strongholds of Carcassonne and Narbonne face severe trials of endurance—likely sieges, battles, or civil strife that test the resolve of their inhabitants.

french: L'œil de Ravenne sera destitué,
Quand à ses pieds les aisles fallliront,
Les deux de Bresse auront constitué
Turin, Verseil que Gaulois fouleront.
english: The eye of Ravenna will be forsaken,
When at its feet the wings will fail,
The two of Bresse will have established
Turin, Vercelli that the Gauls will trample.
6.interpretation: This quatrain describes a military campaign in northern Italy. Ravenna, the strategic 'eye' or lookout, loses its power when its flanking forces ('wings') collapse. Two leaders or cities from the Bresse region (likely Bourg-en-Bresse and another ally) organize an alliance that enables French ('Gaulois') troops to overrun Turin and Vercelli, signaling a French conquest of Piedmont during a period of Italian wars.

french: Tard arriué l'execution faicte
Le vent contraires, lettres au chemin prinses
Les conjurez xiiij d'une secte
Par le Rousseau senez les entreprinses.
english: Late arrived, the execution done,
Contrary winds, letters seized on the way,
The conspirators fourteen of one sect,
By the Rousseau the enterprises will be undertaken.

french: Combien de fois prinse cité solaire
Sera changeant les lois barbares & vaines :
Ton mal s'approche. Plus seras tributaire
La grand Hadrie recourira tes veines.
english: How many times taken, solar city,
You will be, changing the barbaric and vain laws:
Your evil approaches. You will be more tributary,
The great Hadria will reopen your veins.
8.interpretation: A 'solar city'—likely a metaphor for a radiant or powerful metropolis (possibly Rome, Paris, or a heliocentric symbol)—will be captured multiple times, each conquest replacing barbaric and futile laws. As calamity nears, the city becomes increasingly subject to tribute. 'Great Hadria' (the ancient Adriatic Sea, symbolizing Venice) will reopen its vital arteries, restoring maritime trade, influence, or lifeblood after periods of decline.

french: De l'Orient viendra le coeur Punique
Fascher Hadrie, & les hoirs Romulides,
Accompagné de la classe Libyque,
Temple Melites et proches Isles vuides.
english: From the Orient will come the Punic heart
To anger Hadria and the heirs of Romulus,
Accompanied by the Libyan fleet,
Temples of Malta and nearby isles emptied.
9.interpretation: A leader or power with Carthaginian ('Punic') spirit rises from the East, enraging Venice ('Hadria') and the legacy of Rome. Supported by a North African ('Libyan') navy, this force causes the temples and cities of Malta ('Melites') and surrounding islands to be abandoned—evoking a massive Mediterranean naval invasion that depopulates key Christian strongholds.

french: Serpens transmis en la cage de fer,
Où les enfans septains du Roy sont prins,
Les vieux & peres sortiront bas de l'enfer,
Ains mourir voir de fruict mort & cris.
english: Serpent transmitted into the iron cage,
Where the seven-year-old children of the King are taken,
The old and fathers will come out from the depths of hell,
Before dying to see the death and cries of their fruit.
10.interpretation: A serpent (symbol of treachery or poison) is secretly introduced into an iron cage or prison where the king's young heirs—specifically his seven children—are held captive. Ancient progenitors rise as if from hell (perhaps ancestral tombs or long-suppressed forces), only to witness in agony the murder and screams of their royal descendants before perishing themselves.

french: Le mouvement de sens, coeur, pieds & mains,
Seront d'accord Naples, Lyon Sicille
Glaives, feux, eaux puis aux nobles Romains,
Plongez, tuez, morts par cerveau debile.
english: The movement of sense, heart, feet and hands,
Will be in accord: Naples, Lyon, Sicily
Swords, fires, waters, then against the noble Romans,
Plunged, killed, dead by a feeble brain.
11.interpretation: A unified impulse of intellect, emotion, and physical action coordinates across Naples, Lyon, and Sicily, deploying weapons and elemental forces—swords, fires, floods—against the noble Romans (likely papal or imperial authorities). Their downfall comes through drowning, slaughter, and fatal errors stemming from weak or deranged leadership.

french: Dans peu dira faulce brute fragile,
De bas en hault eslevé promptement.
Puis en istant desloyale & labile,
Qui de Veronne aura gouvernement.
english: Soon a false, fragile rumor will be spoken,
Quickly raised from low to high.
Then in an instant disloyal and unstable,
He who will have governance of Verona.
12.interpretation: A deceptive and ephemeral rumor propels an unlikely figure from humble origins to sudden prominence. This treacherous and fickle leader, who seizes control of Verona (evoking the city's history of turbulent lordships like the Scaligeri), will swiftly collapse due to betrayal and instability.

french: Les exilez par ire, haine intestine,
Feront au Roy grand conjuration :
Secret mettront ennemis par la mine,
Et ses vieux siens contre eux sedition.
english: The exiles by wrath, internal hatred,
Will make against the King great conspiracy:
Secretly will put enemies by the mine,
And his old ones against them sedition.
13.interpretation: Exiles driven by rage and civil enmity will plot a grand conspiracy against the monarch. Through covert sabotage—'by the mine' evoking undermining tunnels or treachery—they will target the king's adversaries, yet his veteran allies will revolt against the plotters, exposing profound rifts in the elite.

french: De gent esclave chansons, chants & requestes.
Captifs par Princes & Seigneurs aux prisons :
A l'advenir par idiots sans testes,
Seront receuz par diuines oraisons.
english: From enslaved folk: songs, chants, and requests.
Captives by princes and lords in prisons:
In the future by idiots without heads,
Will be received by divine prayers.
14.interpretation: Expressions of the oppressed—songs, chants, and petitions—emerge from enslaved people, who are imprisoned by tyrannical princes and lords. In times to come, senseless and leaderless fools will be embraced through pious invocations, evoking a future where demagoguery cloaked in religion elevates the unworthy to power.

french: Mars nous menasse par sa force bellique,
Septante fois fera le sang espandre :
Auge & ruyne de l'Ecclesiastique,
Et plus ceux qui d'eux rien voudront entendre.
english: Mars threatens us with his warlike force,
Seventy times the blood will be spilled:
The Auge and ruin of the Ecclesiastical,
And more those who of them nothing will want to hear.
15.interpretation: Mars, the god of war, foretells relentless conflict, spilling blood seventy times—possibly evoking seven decades of strife or repeated calamities. This ushers in the 'Auge' (Augean cleansing, symbolizing the purging of deep-seated corruption in the Church) followed by its profound ruin. Greater woes await those who refuse to heed the Church's pleas or prophetic warnings, amplifying the tragedy through denial.

french: Faulx a l'estang ioincte vers le Sagittaire,
En son hault AUGE de l'exaltation,
Peste, famine, mort de main militaire,
Le siecle approche de renovation.
english: A false (or a sickle) at the stagnant pond points toward Sagittarius,
In its high grade elevation of exaltation,
Plague, famine, death of the military hand:
The century approaches renewal.
16.interpretation: An ill omen (the “false” or “sickle”) near a stagnant water body aligns with the zodiac sign Sagittarius, a sign of high energy. The alignment presages pestilence, famine, and military casualties, but also suggests that the current century will end and a new era will begin.

french: Par quarante ans l'Iris n'apparoistra,
Par quarante ans tous les jours sera veu :
La terre aride en siccité croistra,
Et grand deluges quand sera aperceu.
english: For forty years the Iris will not appear,
For forty years every day will be seen:
The dry earth will increase in drought,
And great floods will be seen when it appears.
17.interpretation: A forty year period of darkness or lack of “Iris” (perhaps a metaphor for rain or a celestial sign). During this time the world suffers severe drought, but when the sign finally returns, massive floods will follow—suggesting a climatic swing from severe dryness to catastrophic flooding.

french: Par la discorde negligence Gauloise
Sera passage à Mahommet ouvert :
De sang trempé la terre & mer Senoise,
Le port Phocen de voilles & nefs couvert.
english: Through discord and neglect, Gaul will be,
A passage opened to Muhammad:
Blood will soak the earth and the sea will be swollen,
The Phoenician harbour will be covered with sails and ships.
18.interpretation: Internal strife and neglect in France (Gaul) will create a pathway for the spread of Islam (“Muhammad”). The ensuing conflict will bathe both land and sea in blood, while the historic Phoenician ports (perhaps Marseille) will be filled with fleets, indicating a large naval confrontation involving Muslim forces.

french: Lors que serpens viendront circuir l'are,
Le sang Troyen vexé par les Espaignes :
Par eux grand nombre en sera fait tare,
Chef suict, caché au mares dans les saignes.
english: When serpents come to circle the altar,
Trojan blood will be angered by the Spaniards,
Through them a great number will be made defective,
A chief, hidden in the marshes, will flee in the blood.
19.interpretation: A wave of betrayal (“serpents”) surrounds a sacred place. The “Trojan” lineage (perhaps a reference to a noble house) will be provoked by Spain, resulting in many casualties or a crippled force. A leader will hide in the marshes and escape amid the carnage.

french: Tours, Orleans, Blois, Angers, Reims & Nantes
Citez vexees par subit changement,
Par langues estranges seront tendues tentes,
Feuves, dars, Renes, terre & mer tremblement.
english: Tours, Orléans, Blois, Angers, Reims, and Nantes,
Cities upset by sudden change:
By foreign tongues tents will be stretched,
Floods, darts, rains, earth and sea trembling.
20.interpretation: A swift, unsettling transformation hits several central French cities. Foreign influence (“strange languages”) spreads, possibly through migration or invasion, leading to natural disasters—floods, storms, and earthquakes—that shake both land and sea.

french: Profonde argile blanche nourrit rocher,
Qui d'un abysme istra lacticineuse,
En vain troublez ne l'oseront toucher,
Ignorant estre au fond terre argilleuse.
english: Deep white clay will nourish the rocky ground,
Which from an abyss will become lacteous,
In vain will the troubled ones dare to touch it,
Ignorant beings will remain at the bottom of the clay earth.
21.interpretation: A subterranean layer of white clay (perhaps a mineral deposit) will feed the stony terrain, turning a deep chasm milky white. Those who try to exploit it will fail, and ignorant peoples will stay buried beneath this clay, suggesting a hidden resource that remains untapped due to lack of knowledge.

french: Ce qui vivra et n'ayant aucun sens,
Viendra leser à mort son artifice,
Autun, Chalons, Langres & les deux Sens,
La grefle et glace fera grand malefice.
english: What will live and have no meaning,
Will come to kill with its artifice:
Autun, Chalon, Langres and the two Sens,
The gravel and ice will do a great mischief.
22.interpretation: A senseless phenomenon or invention will turn lethal. The cities of Autun, Chalon, Langres, and the two “Sens” (likely Sens and Sen-la-Ville) will be affected. A mixture of gravel and ice (perhaps a treacherous road or a flood of frozen debris) will cause a major disaster.

french: Au mois troisiesme se levant le Soleil,
Sanglier liepard, au champ Mars pour combattre
Liepard lassé au Ciel estend son œil,
Un aigle autour du Soleil voit s'esbattre.
english: In the third month, as the sun rises,
A wild boar, a leopard on the March field to fight:
The leopard lifts its eye to the sky,
An eagle around the sun sees itself tumble.
23.interpretation: During March, natural symbols of aggression—the boar and the leopard—appear on battlefields, indicating fierce conflict. The leopard's gaze upward and the eagle's tumbling around the sun hint at a celestial omen, possibly an eclipse or unusual solar phenomenon that is interpreted as a warning of war.

french: A cité neuve pensif pour condamner,
L'oisel de proye au Ciel se vient offrir :
Apres victoire à captifs pardonner,
Cremone & Mantoue grand maux aura souffert.
english: At the new city, thoughtful to condemn,
The bird of prey comes to offer itself to the sky:
After victory, pardon to the captives,
Cremona and Mantua will have suffered great evils.
24.interpretation: In a newly founded city (often identified with Geneva or a reformed stronghold), a predatory power hesitates before passing judgment, then offers itself symbolically to heaven (a sacrificial or divine gesture). After triumph, it grants mercy to prisoners, while the Italian cities of Cremona and Mantua endure terrible devastation during the same conflict.

french: Perdu, trouvé, caché de si long siecle,
Sera pasteur demy Dieu honoré :
Ains que la Lune acheve son grand siecle,
Par autres vents sera deshonoré.
english: Lost, found, hidden for so long a century,
Will be honored as shepherd half-god:
Before the Moon completes its great cycle,
By other winds he will be dishonored.
25.interpretation: A figure or relic long lost and concealed for centuries resurfaces and is venerated as a semi-divine shepherd (a messianic or papal leader). Yet before the completion of a great lunar cycle (often interpreted as a 320–354-year era), shifting political or religious currents will strip him of honor and bring disgrace.

french: Le grand du fouldre tombe d'heure diurne,
Mal & predict par porteur postulaire :
Suivant presage tombe d'heure nocturne,
Conflit Reims, Londres, Etrusque pestifere.
english: The great one struck by lightning falls in daytime,
Evil foretold by a letter-bearing bearer:
Following the omen falls also in nighttime,
Conflict at Reims, London, pestilence in Tuscany.
26.interpretation: A prominent leader is suddenly struck down by lightning (assassination or catastrophe) in broad daylight, an event predicted by a messenger. A second disaster follows at night. War erupts involving Reims and London, while plague ravages Etruria (Tuscany).

french: Dessous de chaine Guien du Ciel frappé,
Non loing de là est caché le tresor,
Qui par long siecles avoit esté grappé,
Trouvé moura, l'œil crevé de ressor.
english: Beneath the oak chain of Guyenne struck from heaven,
Not far from there the treasure is hidden,
That for long centuries had been gathered,
The finder will die, his eye pierced by a spring-shoot.
27.interpretation: Near an oak (or chained oak) in Guyenne, a meteor or lightning strike reveals a treasure hoarded for centuries. The discoverer meets a violent end—his eye pierced by a rebounding metal spring or splinter—suggesting a booby-trapped cache or tragic accident.

french: La tour de Boucq craindra fuste Barbare,
Un temps, long temps apres barque hesperique
Bettail, gens, meubles, tous deux feront grand tare,
Taurus & libra, quelle mortelle picque !
english: The tower of Bouc will fear the barbarian fleet,
For a time, long after the western ship,
Cattle, people, goods—both sides will suffer great loss,
Taurus and Libra: what a deadly quarrel!
28.interpretation: The coastal fortress of Le Bouc (near Marseille) dreads a barbarian (likely Ottoman or North African) navy. After an interval, a western fleet arrives. Both sides inflict and endure massive destruction of livestock, civilians, and property under the astrological clash of Taurus and Libra, signaling a fatal conflict in spring or autumn.

french: Quand le poisson terrestre & aquatique
Par force vague au gravier sera mis,
Sa forme estrange suave & horrifique,
Par mer aux murs bien tost les ennemis.
english: When the fish both of land and water
By a mighty wave is cast upon the gravel,
Its strange form smooth yet horrific,
Very soon by sea the enemies to the walls.
29.interpretation: A tremendous tsunami hurls an amphibious creature—possibly a submarine, sea monster, or grotesque hybrid—onto the shore, its bizarre and terrifying appearance shocking onlookers. Immediately afterward, enemy fleets approach the city walls by sea, linking natural cataclysm to imminent invasion.

french: La nef estrange par le tourment marin,
Abordera pres de port incogneu :
Nonobstant signes de rameau palmerin,
Apres mort pille bon advis tard venu.
english: The foreign ship, through marine torment,
Will approach near an unknown port:
Despite signs of the palm branch,
After death, plunder; good counsel came too late.
30.interpretation: A storm-tossed foreign vessel approaches an unfamiliar harbor bearing olive/palm branches (traditional signs of peace or truce). The gesture is ignored; the crew is killed and the ship looted. Only afterward does wiser counsel arrive, too late to prevent the massacre.

french: Tant d'ans en Gaule les guerres dureront,
Outre la course du Castulon monarque :
Victoire incerte trois grands couronneront,
Aigle, Coq, Lune, Lyon, Soleil en marque.
english: So many years the wars in Gaul will last,
Beyond the reign of the Castulian monarch:
Uncertain victory will crown three great ones,
Eagle, Rooster, Moon, Lion, Sun as emblems.
31.interpretation: Prolonged wars ravage France long after a Spanish or southern monarch (Castulon) is gone. Three major powers—symbolized by the Eagle (Germany/Holy Roman Empire or USA), Rooster (France), Moon (Ottomans/Islam), Lion (England or Netherlands), and Sun (Spain or France itself)—fight to an inconclusive end, each claiming a hollow crown.

french: Le grand Empire sera tost translaté
En lieu petit, qui bien tost viendra croistre,
Lieu bien infime d'exigue comté,
Où au milieu viendra poser son sceptre.
english: The great Empire will soon be transferred
To a small place, which will soon come to grow,
A very lowly spot in a tiny county,
In whose center it will come to plant its scepter.
32.interpretation: A vast empire will shift its seat of power to an insignificant, tiny territory that rapidly expands into a new dominant center—often interpreted as the rise of a small nation or city-state (e.g., Washington D.C., Geneva, or a future micro-power) that inherits global imperial authority.

french: Pres d'un grand pont de plaine spatieuse,
Le grand Lyon par forces Cesarees,
Fera abbattre hors cité rigoureuse,
Par effroy portes luy seront reserrees.
english: Near a great bridge over a spacious plain,
The great Lion by Caesarean forces
Will cause a rigid city to be cast down,
Through terror its gates will be forced open to him.
33.interpretation: Close to a major bridge on open terrain, the French Lion (or a leader bearing the lion emblem), backed by imperial Roman-style legions, storms and razes a fiercely defended city; sheer terror causes the gates to be flung open in surrender.

french: L'oyseau de proye volant à la fenestre,
Avant conflict faict aux François pareure,
L'un bon prendra, l'un ambigu sinistre,
La partie foible tiendra par bon augure.
english: The bird of prey flying to the left window,
Before the conflict offers the French an appearance,
One side will take it as good, one as ambiguous and sinister,
The weaker party will hold it as a good omen.
34.interpretation: A raptor (eagle or ominous bird) flies toward the left (sinister) side before battle, presenting the French with a portent. One faction interprets it favorably, the other sees evil; the weaker side clings to the positive reading and is encouraged by the omen.

french: Le lyon jeune le vieux surmontera,
En champ bellique par singulier duelle,
Dans cage d'or les yeux luy crevera,
Deux classes une puis mourir mort cruelle.
english: The young lion will overcome the older one,
On the field of war in single duel,
In a cage of gold he will pierce his eyes,
Two wounds in one, then to die a cruel death.
35.interpretation: A young lion (Henri II of France or a younger prince) defeats an older lion in single combat during a tournament. Inside a golden cage (gilded lance or helmet visor), the fatal splinter pierces both eyes ('two wounds in one'), leading to an agonizing death—widely accepted as the exact prophecy of Henri II’s death in 1559.

french: Tard le Monarque se viendra repentir,
De n'avoir mis à mort son adversaire,
Mais viendra bien à plus hault consentir,
Que tout son sang par mort fera deffaire.
english: Late the monarch will come to repent
For not having put his adversary to death,
But he will come to consent to a far higher thing,
That all his blood will be undone by death.
36.interpretation: A king bitterly regrets having spared a dangerous rival. Later he agrees to a loftier cause or sacrifice, only for that decision to bring about the violent extinction of his entire royal line.

french: Un peu devant que le Soleil s'absconse,
Conflict donné, grand peuple dubiteux,
Prosligez, port marin ne fait response,
Pont & sepulchre en deux estranges lieux.
english: A little before the Sun conceals itself,
Battle is joined, a great people in doubt,
Prostrated, the maritime port makes no answer,
Bridge and sepulchre in two foreign places.
37.interpretation: Shortly before a solar eclipse, a great battle begins amid widespread uncertainty. A key naval port falls silent and offers no resistance; bridges and tombs are erected or discovered in unexpected foreign lands, suggesting defeat, occupation, and the burial of the fallen far from home.

french: Le Sol & l'Aigle au victeur paroistront,
Response vaine au vaincu l'on asseure,
Par cor ny cris harnois n'arresteront,
Vindicte paix par mors si acheve à l'heure.
english: The Sun and the Eagle will appear to the victor,
Empty reassurance is given to the vanquished,
Neither by horn nor cries will arms be stayed,
Vengeance-peace achieved by death at the right hour.
38.interpretation: The Sun (France or Napoleon) and the Eagle (imperial power) shine upon the triumphant side. The defeated are given false promises of mercy. War horns and battle cries do not cease the slaughter; a final peace is imposed only through decisive killing at the appointed moment.

french: De nuict dans lict le supresme estrangle,
Pour trop avoir sejourné blond esleu,
Par trois l'Empire subroge exancle,
A mort mettra carte, & paquet ne leu.
english: At night in bed the supreme one strangled,
For having stayed too long, the blond chosen one,
By three the Empire is subrogated, exhausted,
To death he will put card and packet unread.
39.interpretation: A supreme ruler (often linked to a French or Russian monarch) is strangled in his bed at night because the fair-haired elected successor lingered too long in exile or hesitation. A triumvirate seizes and drains the empire; the new leader dies after issuing a fatal decree ('card and packet') that is never opened or acted upon.

french: La trombe fausse dissimulant folie,
Fera Bisance un changement de loix.
Histra d'Egypte, qui veut que l'on deslie,
Edict changeant monnoye & aloys.
english: The false trumpet concealing madness
Will cause Byzantium a change of laws:
Outcry from Egypt, who wants the edict loosened,
Edict changing coinage and alloys.
40.interpretation: A deceitful leader or proclamation (the 'false trumpet') hiding insanity will force revolutionary legal changes upon Constantinople/Byzantium (often symbolising the Eastern or Orthodox world). Hysterical demands from Egypt pressure the loosening of restrictions, culminating in an edict that debases currency and metal standards, triggering economic chaos.

french: Siege en cité est de nuict assaillie,
Peu eschapé, non loin de mer conflict,
Femme de joye, retours fils defaillie,
Poison & lettres cachees dans le plic.
english: The city under siege is assaulted by night,
Few escape: not far from the sea the battle,
Woman transported with joy, the son’s return fails,
Poison and letters hidden in the liquor.
41.interpretation: A coastal city is stormed at night with few survivors. A woman who rejoiced at her son’s expected return instead receives his corpse; hidden among the belongings are poison and incriminating letters concealed in a folded document or flask.

french: Le dix Calende d'Avril de faict Gotique
Resuscité encor par gens malins,
Le feu estainct, assemblee diabolique,
Cherchant les os du d'Amant & Pselin.
english: The tenth of the Kalends of April in Gothic deed
Revived again by malicious people:
The fire extinguished, diabolical assembly
Seeking the bones of the demon and Psellos.
42.interpretation: On 23 March (old calendar), a dark, Gothic-style atrocity is resurrected by evil men. A sacred or perpetual fire is put out, and a satanic gathering searches for the relics of the demon Asmodeus ('d'Amant') and the Byzantine scholar Michael Psellos, evoking a resurgence of black magic and occult desecration.

french: Avant qu'advienne le changement d'Empire,
Il adviendra un cas bien merveilleux,
Le champ mué, le pillier de Porphire
Mis, transmué sus le rocher noilleux.
english: Before the change of Empire occurs,
A very wondrous event will take place,
The field shifted, the porphyry pillar
Placed and transferred onto the gnarled rock.
43.interpretation: Immediately before an imperial power shift, a miraculous sign appears: a battlefield dramatically alters, and a great porphyry column (ancient symbol of Roman/Byzantine imperial authority) is moved and set upon a rugged, knotted rock—signifying the transfer of world dominion to a new, rough-hewn power.

french: En bref seront de retour sacrifices,
Contrevenants seront mis à martyre :
Plus ne seront moines, abbez, ne novices,
Le miel sera beaucoup plus cher que cire.
english: Soon sacrifices will return,
Those who contravene will be put to martyrdom:
There will be no more monks, abbots, nor novices,
Honey will be much more expensive than wax.
44.interpretation: Pagan or bloody sacrifices briefly reappear; dissenters are martyred. Monasteries are emptied, and the Church’s production collapses to the point that honey (once a monastic by-product) becomes far costlier than candle-wax, marking a swift return to pre-Christian brutality and the destruction of organised monasticism.

french: Secteur de sectes grand peine au delateur,
Beste en theatre, dresse le jeu scenique,
Du faict antique ennobly l'inventeur,
Par sectes monde confus & schismatique.
english: Founder of sects, great trouble to the informer,
Beast in the theatre, the stage-play set up,
The ancient deed ennobled by the inventor,
Through sects the world confused and schismatic.
45.interpretation: The originator of new sects causes torment to spies and accusers. A monstrous spectacle is staged in the theatre of the world; ancient tragedy is glorified anew by its creator, plunging civilisation into chaotic, schismatic division.

french: Tout apres d'Aux, de Lestore & Mirande,
Grand feu du ciel en trois nuicts tombera :
Cause adviendra bien stupende & Mirande,
Bien peu apres la terre tremblera.
english: Very near Auch, Lectoure and Mirande,
Great fire from the sky will fall for three nights:
A most stupendous and miraculous event will occur,
Very soon afterwards the earth will tremble.
46.interpretation: In south-western France near Auch, Lectoure, and Mirande, a blazing celestial object (meteorite or comet fragment) will rain fire for three consecutive nights. An astonishing, miraculous phenomenon follows, and shortly thereafter a violent earthquake strikes the same region.

french: Du lac Leman les sermons fascheront,
Des jours seront reduicts par des semaines,
Puis mois, puis an, puis tous defailliront,
Les Magistrats damneront leurs lois vaines.
english: The speeches from Lake Geneva will annoy,
Days will be reduced to weeks,
Then months, then years; then all will fail,
The magistrates will condemn their useless laws.
47.interpretation: Fiery Calvinist sermons from Geneva provoke widespread anger. Time itself seems accelerated—days feel like weeks—as crisis deepens; eventually societal order collapses, and authorities publicly declare their own laws futile.

french: Vingt ans du regne de la Lune passez,
Sept mille ans autre tiendra sa monarchie :
Quand le Soleil prendra ses jours lassez,
Lors accomplir & mine ma prophetie.
english: Twenty years of the reign of the Moon passed,
Seven thousand years another will hold its monarchy:
When the Sun takes up its weary days,
Then my prophecy is accomplished and finished.
48.interpretation: After a brief Islamic lunar era of twenty years, a new power (often interpreted as a revived Christian or solar dominion) will rule for seven millennia. When the exhausted Sun resumes its cycle, Nostradamus declares his entire prophetic work fulfilled and completed.

french: Beaucoup avant telle menees,
Ceux d'Orient par la vertu lunaire :
L'an mil sept cens feront grand emmenees,
Subjugant presque le coing Aquilonaire.
english: Long before such events,
Those of the East, by the power of the Moon,
In the year one thousand seven hundred will make great advances,
Almost subjugating the northern corner.
49.interpretation: Far in advance of the final upheavals, Eastern (Islamic or Asian) forces empowered by the crescent Moon will, around the year 1700, launch massive invasions that nearly conquer the entire northern (European/Aquilon) quadrant.

french: De l'aquatique triplicité naistra,
D'un qui fera le Jeudy pour sa feste :
Son bruit, loz, regne, sa puissance croistra,
Par terre & mer aux Oriens tempeste.
english: From the aquatic triplicity will be born
One who will make Thursday his holiday:
His fame, praise, reign, and power will grow,
By land and sea causing tempests to the East.
50.interpretation: Born under the three water signs (Cancer, Scorpio, Pisces), a leader who reveres Thursday (Jupiter’s day) will rise to immense fame and power, unleashing storms of war by land and sea against the Orient—widely seen as a prophecy of a great anti-Islamic conqueror.

french: Chefs d'Aries, Jupiter & Saturne,
Dieu eternel quelles mutations !
Puis par long siecle son maling temps retourne
Gaule & Italie, quelles esmotions !
english: Heads of Aries, Jupiter and Saturn,
Eternal God, what revolutions!
Then after a long century its evil time returns,
Gaul and Italy, what upheavals!
51.interpretation: A rare conjunction of Jupiter and Saturn in Aries signals massive cosmic and earthly revolutions. After a long century of relative calm, the malign era returns with renewed force, bringing violent turmoil to France (Gaul) and Italy.

french: Les deux malins de Scorpion conjoincts,
Le grand seigneur meurdry dedans la salle :
Peste à l'Eglise par le nouveau Roy joinct,
L'Europe basse & Septentrionale.
english: The two malefics of Scorpio conjoined,
The great lord murdered inside his hall:
Plague to the Church by the new joined king,
Lower and Northern Europe.
52.interpretation: When Mars and Saturn (the two malefics) are conjoined in Scorpio, a high noble is assassinated in his own palace. A newly enthroned king (or alliance of kings) unleashes persecution against the Church, afflicting both southern and northern Europe.

french: Las qu'on verra grand peuple tourmenté,
Et la loy saincte en totale ruine,
Par autres loix toute la Chrestienté,
Quand d'or d'argent trouve nouvelle mine.
english: Alas, that one will see a great people tormented,
And the holy law in total ruin,
By other laws all Christendom troubled,
When new mines of gold and silver are found.
53.interpretation: A great nation suffers torment while traditional religion is utterly destroyed. New secular or revolutionary laws dominate Christendom, triggered or financed by the discovery of vast new sources of gold and silver (often linked to the conquest of the Americas).

french: Deux revolts faits du maling facigere,
De regne & siecles fait permutation :
Le mobil signe à son endroit si ingere,
Aux deux esgaux & d'inclination.
english: Two revolts made by the malignant sickle-bearer,
Of reign and centuries makes permutation:
The mobile sign to its proper place so applies itself,
To the two equal and inclined.
54.interpretation: Two revolutions are instigated by a sinister sickle-wielder (often Saturn or a revolutionary figure). These upheavals overturn kingdoms and entire eras. A mutable astrological sign (Gemini, Virgo, Sagittarius or Pisces) aligns perfectly, bringing two equal powers into balanced inclination.

french: Sous l'opposite climat Babylonique,
Grande sera de sang effusion,
Que terre & mer, air, ciel sera inique,
Sectes, faim, regnes, pestes, confusion.
english: Under the climate opposite to Babylon,
Great will be the shedding of blood,
So that land and sea, air, sky will be unjust:
Sects, famine, kingdoms, plagues, confusion.
55.interpretation: In a land of extreme climate opposite ancient Babylon’s (often interpreted as the New World or far north/south), immense slaughter occurs. The entire natural order is thrown into iniquity, producing religious sects, starvation, collapsing kingdoms, pandemics, and total chaos.

french: Vous verrez tost & tard faire grand change,
Horreurs extremes & vindications :
Que si la lune conduicte par son ange,
Le ciel s'approche des inclinations.
english: You will see sooner and later great changes made,
Extreme horrors and vindications:
That if the Moon is guided by its angel,
The sky approaches the inclinations.
56.interpretation: Both soon and in the distant future, cataclysmic transformations bring terror followed by righteous vengeance. If the Moon (Islam or a lunar power) is guided by its celestial angel, the heavens themselves draw near to earthly inclinations—signalling a divinely sanctioned shift in world order.

french: Par grand discord la trombe tremblera,
Accord rompu dressant la teste au ciel,
Bouche sanglante dans le sang nagera,
Au sol la face ointe de laict & miel.
english: By great discord the trumpet will tremble,
Agreement broken, head raised to the sky:
Bloody mouth will swim in blood,
On the ground the face anointed with milk and honey.
57.interpretation: Massive discord causes even the war trumpet to shake. Treaties are shattered, defiant cries rise heavenward. After savage slaughter, the fallen land is paradoxically marked with milk and honey—symbolising a promised fertile peace born from horrific war.

french: Tranché le ventre naistra avec deux testes,
Et quatre bras, quelques ans entiers vivra !
Jour qui Alquiloye celebrera ses festes
Fossen, Turin, chief Ferrare suyvra.
english: Cut in the belly, born with two heads
And four arms: it will live whole years!
The day that Alquiloye celebrates its feasts,
Fosson, Turin, the leader Ferrara will follow.
58.interpretation: A monstrous birth—ripped from the womb with two heads and four arms—survives several years as a living portent. On the feast day of Aquileia (Alquiloye), the cities of Fossano, Turin, and Ferrara fall under its influence or that of its symbolic regime.

french: Les exilez deportez dans les Isles
Au changement d'un plus cruel Monarque
Seront meurtris, & mis deux les scintiles,
Qui de parler ne seront estez parques.
english: The exiles deported to the islands
At the change to a more cruel Monarch
Will be murdered, and two put on the spits,
Who of speaking will not be spared.
59.interpretation: Political exiles banished to islands suffer slaughter when an even harsher tyrant seizes power. Two prominent captives are roasted alive on spits and denied even the mercy of silence—evoking brutal penal colonies and savage repression.

french: Un Empereur naistra pres d'Italie,
Qui a l'Empire sera vendu bien cher,
Diront avec quels gens il se ralie,
Qu'on trouvera moins prince que boucher.
english: An Emperor will be born near Italy,
Who to the Empire will be sold very dear,
They will say with what people he allies himself,
That he will be found less prince than butcher.
60.interpretation: An emperor emerges close to Italy (often identified with Napoleon) whose rise costs the empire an enormous price in blood and treasure. His choice of allies reveals him to be less a noble ruler than a merciless butcher.

french: La republique miserable infelice
Sera vastée du nouueau magistrat,
Leur grand amas de l'exil malefice
Fera Sueve raur leur grand contract.
english: The wretched unhappy republic
Will be laid waste by the new magistrate:
Their great hoard of malignant exile
Will make the Swabians ravage their great contract.
61.interpretation: A fragile and unfortunate republic is devastated by a newly installed leader. The massive wealth accumulated through harmful exile policies provokes the Swabians (southern Germans) to tear up a major treaty, signalling the violent collapse of a revolutionary government.

french: La grande perte, las que feront les lettres,
Avant le Ciel de Latona parfaict,
Feu grand deluge plus par ignares sceptres,
Que de long siecle ne se verra refaict.
english: The great loss, alas, that letters will cause,
Before the cycle of Latona is perfected:
Great fire, greater flood through ignorant rulers,
That for a long century will not be repaired.
62.interpretation: Decrees and written laws bring catastrophic loss. Before a complete lunar cycle (often linked to revolutionary or Islamic time), ignorant tyrants unleash fire and flood on a scale that leaves devastation unhealed for over a hundred years.

french: Les fleurs passez diminue le monde,
Long temps la paix terres inhabitées,
Seur marchera par Ciel, terre, mer, & onde,
Puis de nouueau les guerres suscitées.
english: The past plagues diminished the world,
Long time peace, lands uninhabited:
Safe one will travel by sky, land, sea and wave,
Then again wars will be stirred up.
63.interpretation: After devastating pandemics drastically reduce the population, a long era of peace settles over depopulated lands. Safe travel resumes across all elements, only for new wars to erupt and shatter the calm.

french: De nuict Soleil penseront avoir veu
Quand le pourceau demy homme on verra.
Bruit, chant, bataille au Ciel battre aperceu,
Et bestes brutes a parler l'on orra.
english: At night they will think they have seen the Sun,
When the half-pig man is seen:
Noise, song, battle perceived beating in the sky,
And brute beasts will be heard to speak.
64.interpretation: A terrifying nocturnal illusion of a second sun (nuclear flash or comet) coincides with the appearance of a grotesque half-human, half-pig monster. The sky resounds with inexplicable noises and battles; even animals seem to speak—classic apocalyptic imagery of the end times.

french: Enfant sans mains Jamais veu si grand foudre,
L'enfant Royal au jeu d'œsteuf blessé,
Au puy brises fulgures allant mouldre,
Trois souz les chaines par le milieu troussez.
english: Child without hands, never seen such great lightning,
The royal child wounded at the game of tennis:
At the hill, broken ones, lightning going to grind,
Three under the chains through the middle trussed.
65.interpretation: A handicapped child witnesses an unprecedented lightning storm. A royal prince is fatally wounded by a splinter at a tennis match (echoing Henri II’s death). On a hill, lightning pulverises victims; three chained prisoners are torn apart at the waist.

french: Celuy qui lors portera les nouvelles,
Apres un il viendra respirer,
Viviers, Tournon, Montferrant & Pradelles,
Gresle & tempeste le fera souspirer.
english: He who then will carry the news,
After a little while will come to catch his breath:
Viviers, Tournon, Montferrand and Pradelles,
Hail and storm will make him sigh.
66.interpretation: A messenger bringing grave tidings pauses to recover in southern French towns (Viviers, Tournon, Montferrand, Pradelles). Violent hailstorms and tempests ravage the region, adding natural disaster to the bad news.

french: La grand famine que je sens approcher,
Souvent tourner, puis êstre universelle,
Si grande & longue qu'on viendra arracher
Du bois racine, & l'enfant de mammelle.
english: The great famine that I feel approaching,
Often shifting, then becoming universal:
So great and long that one will come to tear
Root from wood, and infant from the breast.
67.interpretation: An approaching famine begins regionally, spreads globally, and lasts so long that people gnaw tree roots and snatch nursing infants from mothers—either for food or in despair—depicting utter societal collapse.

french: O quel horrible & mal'heureux tourment,
Trois innocens qu'on viendra à livrer,
Poison suspecte, mal gardé tradiment,
Mis en horreur par bourreaux enyvrez.
english: O what a horrible and unhappy torment,
Three innocents whom one will come to deliver up:
Suspected poison, badly guarded betrayal,
Put in horror by drunken executioners.
68.interpretation: Three innocent children (often linked to the Romanov princesses or French royal heirs) are handed over for execution. Poison is suspected but poorly administered; drunken executioners botch the job, prolonging the victims’ terror.

french: La grand montagne ronde de sept stades,
Apres paix, guerre, faim, inondation,
Roulera loin abismant grands contrades,
Mesmes antiques, & grand fondation.
english: The great round mountain of seven stadia,
After peace, war, famine, flooding,
Will roll far, engulfing great countries,
Even ancient ones and great foundation.
69.interpretation: A colossal seven-tiered mountain (volcano, asteroid, or symbolic world power) remains dormant through peace, then unleashes war, famine, and floods. It rolls destructively across vast distances, swallowing even the most ancient civilisations and their foundations.

french: Pluye, faim, guerre en Perse non cessée,
La foy trop grande trahira le monarque :
Par la finie en Gaule commencée,
Secret augure pour à un êstre parque.
english: Rain, famine, war in Persia unceasing,
Too great faith will betray the monarch:
Ended there, begun in Gaul,
Secret omen for one to be sparing.
70.interpretation: Endless rain, famine, and war plague Persia/Iran. The monarch’s excessive religious zeal leads to his betrayal. The conflict that ends in the East ignites in France, guided by a hidden prophecy that spares a single individual.

french: La tour marine trois foys prise & reprise,
Par Espagnols, barbares, Ligurins :
Marseille & Aix, Arles par ceux de Pise,
Vast, feu, fer, pillé AVignon des Thurins.
english: The marine tower three times taken and retaken,
By Spaniards, barbarians, Ligurians:
Marseille and Aix, Arles by those of Pisa,
Devastation, fire, sword, Avignon pillaged by Turin.
71.interpretation: A key coastal fortress changes hands three times among Spanish, North African, and Ligurian forces. Marseille, Aix, and Arles fall to Pisan troops; Avignon is sacked by Piedmontese (Turin) armies—depicting a chaotic war for control of southern France.

french: Du tout Marseille des habitans changée,
Course & poursuitte jusques aupres de Lyon,
Narbon, Toloze, par Bourdeaux outragee,
Tuez captifs presque d'un million.
english: Throughout Marseille the inhabitants changed,
Flight and pursuit as far as near Lyon,
Narbonne, Toulouse by Bordeaux outraged,
Killed, captives almost a million.
72.interpretation: Marseille’s population is completely replaced or expelled. Refugees flee northward toward Lyon; Narbonne and Toulouse suffer atrocities at Bordeaux’s hands. Nearly a million are killed or captured in a brutal French civil war.

french: France à cinq pars par neglect assaillie,
Tunys, Argal esmeuz par Persiens :
Leon, Seville, Barcellonne faillie,
N'aura la classe par les Venitiens.
english: France on five sides through neglect assaulted,
Tunis, Algiers stirred up by Persians:
León, Seville, Barcelona having failed,
Will not have the fleet because of the Venetians.
73.interpretation: France is attacked from five directions due to negligence. Persian-backed forces activate Tunis and Algiers. Spanish cities (León, Seville, Barcelona) fall, and Venice withholds naval support, leaving France isolated.

french: Apres sejourné vogueront en Epire,
Le grand secours viendra vers Antioche :
Le noir poil crespe tendra fort à l'Empire,
Barbe d'ærain se rostira en broche.
english: After sojourn they will sail toward Epirus,
The great help will come toward Antioch:
The black curly-haired one will strive hard for the Empire,
Bronze-beard will be roasted on a spit.
74.interpretation: After a pause, fleets sail from western Greece (Epirus) to relieve Antioch. A dark, curly-haired leader (often Seljuk or Ottoman) fights fiercely for dominion, while a bronze-bearded ruler (Byzantine or Crusader) is captured and executed.

french: Le tyran Sienne occupera Savonne,
Le fort gaigné tiendra classe marine :
Les deux armées par la marque d'Anconne,
Par effrayeur le chef s'en examine.
english: The tyrant Siena will occupy Savona,
The fort won will hold the naval fleet:
The two armies through the march of Ancona,
Through fear the leader examines himself.
75.interpretation: A tyrant from Siena seizes Savona and its fleet. Two armies advance via Ancona, terrifying their own commander into deep self-doubt or suicidal despair.

french: D'un nom farouche tel proferé sera,
Que les trois seurs auront fato le nom :
Puis grand peuple par langue & faict dira,
Plus que nul autre aura bruit & renom.
english: With such a fierce name it will be pronounced,
That the three sisters will have Fate the name:
Then a great people by tongue and deed will speak,
More than any other it will have fame and renown.
76.interpretation: A fearsome name (often interpreted as ‘Hitler’ via anagram or ‘Nazi’) is borne by destiny (the three sisters = the Fates). A great nation rises through propaganda and action, achieving infamy unmatched in history.

french: Entre deux mers dressera promontoire,
Que puis mourra par le mors du cheual :
Le sien Neptune pliera voile noire,
Par Calpre & classe aupres de Rocheval.
english: Between two seas will erect a promontory,
That then will die by the bite of the horse:
Their own Neptune will fold black sail,
By Gibraltar and the fleet near Rocheval.
77.interpretation: A power builds a strategic stronghold between two seas (often Gibraltar). It later falls to cavalry ('horse bite'). Its navy lowers black sails in mourning; the decisive battle occurs near Gibraltar and Rocheval (Rochelle or a rock fortress).

french: D'un chief vieillard naistra sens hebeté,
Degenerant par sçavoir & par armes :
Le chef de France par sa sœur redouté,
Champs divisez, concedez aux gendarmes.
english: From an old chief will be born one of dulled wits,
Degenerating by knowledge and by arms:
The leader of France feared by his sister,
Fields divided, granted to the gendarmes.
78.interpretation: An ageing ruler sires a feeble-minded heir who squanders both learning and military strength. The French leader is dreaded even by his own sister; farmland is carved up and handed to military police, signalling decline and internal repression.

french: Bazar, Lestore, Condon, Ausch, Agine,
Esmeus par loix, querelle & monopole :
Car Bourd. Tholoze Bay mettra en ruine,
Renouveller voulant leur tauropole.
english: Bazas, Lectoure, Condom, Auch, Agen,
Stirred up by laws, quarrel and monopoly:
For Bordeaux, Toulouse, Bayonne will be ruined,
Wanting to renew their bull-ring.
79.interpretation: Gascony towns (Bazas, Lectoure, Condom, Auch, Agen) revolt against oppressive laws and monopolies. Bordeaux, Toulouse, and Bayonne are destroyed in the conflict; survivors attempt to revive ancient pagan rites ('tauropole' = bull-sacrifice).

french: De la sixiesme claire splendeur celeste,
Viendra tonner si fort en la Bourgongne,
Puis naistra monstre de tres hideuse beste,
Mars, Avril, May, Juin grand charpin & rongne.
english: From the sixth bright celestial splendour
It will thunder so strongly in Burgundy,
Then will be born a monster of most hideous beast:
March, April, May, June great tearing and rending.
80.interpretation: A brilliant celestial event (comet or supernova) heralds devastating storms in Burgundy. From this turmoil a monstrous power emerges. The months March to June see relentless destruction, slaughter, and gnawing famine.

french: D'humain troupeau neuf seront mis à part
De iugement & conseil separés:
Leur fort sera diuisé en depart
Kappa, Thita, Lambda mors bannis esgarés.
english: Nine will be set apart from the human flock,
From judgment and separated counsel:
Their strength will be divided in parts,
Kappa, Theta, Lambda dead, banished, astray.
81.interpretation: A new group of people will be isolated from the main society, deprived of legal and advisory structures. Their power will be fragmented, leaving them hidden, scattered and effectively exiled.

french: Quand les colomnes de bois grande tremblée
D'Auster conduicte couuerte de rubriche
Tant vuidera dehors grand assemblée,
Trembler Vienne & le païs d'Austriche.
english: When the great wooden columns shake,
From the south a covered rubric appears,
A great assembly will be emptied outside,
Vienna and the country of Austria will tremble.
82.interpretation: A massive structural collapse (perhaps a bridge or church) in the south triggers panic that dissolves gatherings. The disturbance spreads to Austria, causing political and social tremors in Vienna.

french: La gent estrange diuisera butins,
Saturne en Mars son regard furieux:
Horrible strage aux Tosquans & Latins,
Grecs,qui seront à frapper curieux.
english: The foreign people will divide the spoils,
Saturn in March with his furious gaze:
A horrible wreck to the Tosquans and Latins,
Greeks, who will be struck out of curiosity.
83.interpretation: Outsiders will share loot after a battle. An astrological influence (Saturn in March) brings a violent calamity to the peoples of the Iberian Peninsula (“Tosquans”) and the Latins, while the Greeks become collateral victims—suggesting a broad, pan European war under a harsh planetary alignment.

french: Lune obscurcie aux profondes tenebres,
Son frere passe de couleur ferrugine:
Le grand caché long temps sous les latebres,
Tiedera fer dans la plaie sanguine.
english: Moon darkened in deep shadows,
Its brother passes in rusty colour,
The great hidden one long beneath the shadows,
Will bind iron in the bloody wound.
84.interpretation: A lunar eclipse (dark moon) will be accompanied by a reddish companion (perhaps Mars). A long concealed force will emerge, using iron (weapons) to seal a bloody conflict—signalling a sudden, iron clad war after a period of obscurity.

french: Par la response de dame,roy troublé:
Ambadassadeurs mespriseront leur vie:
Le grand ses freres contrefera doublé
Par deus mourront,ire,haine,enuie.
english: By the lady's reply, the king is disturbed:
Ambassadors will despise their own lives:
The great will double his brothers' offense,
Two will die, anger, hatred, enmity.
85.interpretation: A queen's answer unsettles the monarch, leading diplomats to act recklessly. A powerful figure will repeat the wrongdoing of his siblings, resulting in the death of two individuals and the spread of anger and hatred—a cascade of political intrigue.

french: La grande royne quand se verta vaincu,
Fera exces de masculin courraige:
Sus cheual,fluue passera toute nue,
Suite par fer: à foy fera oultrage.
english: When the great queen sees herself defeated,
She will overdo masculine courage:
On a horse, blood will run completely naked,
Followed by iron: at fire it will cause outrage.
86.interpretation: A defeated queen will overcompensate with overtly aggressive, masculine actions. A battle on horseback will be blood soaked, and iron weapons will ignite controversy—signaling a violent, gender role challenged conflict after a royal loss.

french: Ennosigée feu du centre de terre
Fera trembler au tour de cité neusue:
Deux grands rochiers long temps feront la guerre
Puis Arethusa rougira nouueau fleuue.
english: A hidden fire from the earth's centre
Will make the surrounding new city tremble:
Two great rocks will wage war for a long time,
Then Arethusa will redden a new river.
87.interpretation: A subterranean eruption (volcano) will shake a newly founded city. Two massive fortresses (the “great rocks”) will engage in prolonged conflict, after which the river Arethusa (or a waterway) will turn red—likely from blood or lava—symbolising a cataclysmic uprising.

french: Le diuin mal surprendra le grand prince
Vn peu deuant aura femme espousée,
Son puy & credit à vn coup viendra mince,
Conseil mourra pour la teste rasée.
english: The divine evil will surprise the great prince,
A little before he will have a married wife,
His hill and credit will come to a thin blow,
Council will die for the shaved head.
88.interpretation: A hidden malignant force will catch a powerful ruler offguard shortly after his marriage. His stature and reputation will be reduced to nothing by a single strike, and his advisory council will be eliminated (perhaps by beheading)—foretelling a sudden topple of a princely dynasty.

french: Touts ceux de Ilerde seront dedans Mosselle,
Metans à mort tous ceux de Loyre & Seine:
Secours marin viendra pres d'haulte velle
Quand Hespagnols ouurira toute veine.
english: All those of the world will be within Mosselle,
Murder will take all those of the Loire & Seine:
Naval aid will arrive near the high vale,
When the Spaniards will open every vein.
89.interpretation: A catastrophe will gather people in the town of Mosselle, while mass killings sweep the regions of the Loire and Seine rivers. Naval forces will intervene nearby, but Spanish troops will cut off all lines of supply (“open every vein”), indicating a brutal invasion of France's heartland.

french: Bourdeaux,Poitiers,au son de la campane,
A grande classe ira iusques à l'Angon,
Contre Gauloys sera leur tramontane,
Quand monstres hideux naistra près de Orgon.
english: Bordeaux, Poitiers, at the sound of the bell,
A great force will go as far as Angers,
Against the Gauls will be their southwest wind,
When hideous monsters are born near Orgon.
90.interpretation: The ringing of church bells in Bordeaux and Poitiers signals a massive army moving toward Angers. A fierce “south west wind” (metaphor for a military surge) will confront the French, and grotesque “monsters” perhaps barbarian war bands will appear near Orgon, heralding a dreadful invasion.

french: Les dieux feront aux humains apparence,
Ce quils seront auteurs de grand conflit:
Auant ciel veu serain espée & lance,
Que vers main gauche sera plus grand afflit
english: The gods will appear to humans,
They will be authors of a great conflict:
Before the sky sees a serene sword and spear,
Which to the left hand will be a greater affliction.
91.interpretation: Divine apparitions will inspire humans to start a massive war. Before the heavens witness a calm battle (sword and spear), a greater misfortune will strike those who wield the weapons left handed perhaps a symbolic warning about a misguided side of the conflict.

french: Sous vn la paix par tout sera clamée,
Mais non long temps pille & rebellion,
Par refus ville, terre & mer entamée,
Morts & captifz le tiers d'un milion.
english: A peace will be proclaimed everywhere,
But not for long; plunder and rebellion will follow,
Through refusal of city, land and sea,
Dead and captive a third of a million.
92.interpretation: A proclaimed universal peace will be short lived. Soon after, looting and uprising erupt, as cities, lands and seas reject the settlement. The result will be roughly 300,000 deaths and captives, indicating a massive, disastrous collapse of the peace treaty.

french: Terre Italique pres des monts tremblera,
Lyon & coq non trop confederés,
En lieu de peur l'un l'autre saidera
Seul Castulon & Celtes moderés.
english: Italian land near the mountains will tremble,
Lyon and the rooster (France) not too allied,
In place of fear each will aid the other,
Only Castulon and moderate Celts.
93.interpretation: The mountainous regions of Italy will experience earthquakes or turmoil. French factions (Lyon and the symbolic rooster) will stay loosely allied, but mutual aid will replace fear. Only the region of Castulon (perhaps a fictional stronghold) and moderate Celtic groups will remain stable, hinting at a fragmented but cooperative front.

french: Au port Selin le tyran mis à mort
La liberté non pourtant recouurée:
Le nouveau Mars par vindicte & remort:
Dame par force de frayeur honorée.
english: At the port of Selin the tyrant was killed,
Freedom was not yet restored:
The new Mars (war) by vengeance and death:
Lady honoured by the force of fear.
94.interpretation: A tyrant is slain at the harbor of Selin, yet liberty does not immediately return. A renewed war (“Mars”) driven by revenge brings further bloodshed, while a woman (perhaps a queen or martyr) is celebrated through fear—illustrating a cycle of violent power change.

french: Devant moustier trouvé enfant besson
D'heroic sang de moine & vestutisque:
Son bruit par secte langue & puissance son
Qu'on dira fort eleué le vopisque.
english: Before the mounted one was found a mute child,
Of heroic monk's blood and vestal mystery:
His fame by sect, language and power,
Will be said to be highly elevated, the Vopsique.
95.interpretation: Prior to a cavalry commander's rise, a silent child of noble (monastic) lineage appears. His reputation spreads through sectarian support, language, and power, eventually being exalted to a legendary status (“Vopsique” likely a corrupted term for a mythic hero).

french: Celui qu'aura la charge de destruire
Temples,& sectes, changés par fantasie,
Plus aux rochiers qu'aux viuans viendra nuire
Par langue ornée d'oreilles ressaisies.
english: He who will have the task of destroying
Temples and sects, altered by fantasy,
Will harm more the rocks than the living,
By a language adorned with reclaimed ears.
96.interpretation: A designated destroyer will attack religious sites, driven by imagined motives. His campaign will impact stone structures (castles, monasteries) more than people, and he will use a twisted, revived tongue—perhaps an archaic language—to legitimize his destruction.

french: Ce que fer flamme n'asceu paracheuer,
La doulce langue au conseil viendra faire.
Par repos, songe, le roy fera resuer.
Plus l'ennemi en feu, sang militaire.
english: What flame does not finish will be completed,
The sweet tongue will come to counsel,
Through rest and dream, the king will revive,
The more the enemy is on fire, military blood.
97.interpretation: Unfinished fiery actions will be completed later. A persuasive voice will advise the ruler, who, after a period of rest or vision, will regain strength. The enemy's burning (literal or metaphorical) will cause further military bloodshed—suggesting a resurgence after a pause.

french: Le chef qu'aura conduit peuple infini
Loing de son ciel, de meurs & langue estrange:
Cinq mil en Crete & Thessale fini,
Le chef fuiant sauvé en marine grange.
english: The leader who will guide an endless people,
Far from his heaven, from dead and foreign tongue:
Five thousand in Crete and Thessaly will end,
The fleeing leader will be saved in a marine barn.
98.interpretation: A charismatic ruler will lead a massive, wandering populace far from its original homeland, dealing with death and a foreign language. Around five thousand in Crete and Thessaly will perish, while the leader escapes aboard a naval vessel—indicating a disastrous migration and a narrow escape for its commander.

french: Le grand monarque que fera compaignie
Avec deux roys unis par amitié:
O quel soupir fera la grande mesnie:
Enfants Narbon à l'entour quel pitié!
english: The great monarch will have company,
With two kings united by friendship:
Oh, what sigh will make the great household,
Children of Narbonne around, what pity!
99.interpretation: A supreme ruler will be accompanied by two allied kings. Their alliance will cause a sigh of resignation for the great court, while the children of Narbonne suffer—signalling an alliance that marginalises local populations.

french: Long temps au ciel sera veu gris oiseau
Au pres de Dole & de Tousquane terre,
Tenant au bec vn verdoiant rameau,
Mourra tost grand, & finira la guerre.
english: For a long time a grey bird will be seen in the sky,
Near Dole and the land of Tousquane,
Holding a greenish branch in its beak,
Soon a great one will die and the war will end.
100.interpretation: A long lasting grey bird (perhaps a raven) will appear over the regions of Dole and Tousquane, bearing a budding branch—a symbol of new hope. Soon after, a great leader will die, bringing the conflict to a close.
